title: Denied: memo lists Morgans’ rejection of problem-branch claims
text:
But the Financial Review earlier this year revealed Morgans' own compliance officers were detailing problems for years leading up to 2012 at its branch in Springwood, south-east of Brisbane. The branch was headed by David Wilkins, who promoted an “income machine” strategy and split from Morgans in April 2011.

The strategy used options, which are contracts to buy or sell shares. “The strategy involved mainly clients holding a portfolio of shares and a cash account with a cash balance, clients then sell a number of put option contracts to generate income,” the ASIC memo said.

“[A] review found a number of possible contraventions by the advisers concerned primarily inappropriate advice,” it said.

Some clients have since claimed they lost hundreds of thousands of dollars each.

But the toll from clients losses in the matter was “unknown”, the 2012 memo said.

“Morgans has been generally denying liability when claims have been lodged with it and referring clients to the [Financial Ombudsman Service] where it will take some time for the matters to be resolved,” the memo said.

The memo comes despite Morgans own compliance reviews years earlier having found multiple problems at the branch. One Morgans email, detailed in a separate lawsuit, showed how top brass by February 2009 – three years earlier – had determined “Springwood have a one-size-fits-all policy – i.e. a trend towards a margin loans and options strategy”.

Advertisement

ASIC banned Mr Wilkins from providing financial services for five years from 2015, saying he had engaged in misleading conduct by representing that “options trading carried little to no risk”.

Another August 2013 email obtained by freedom of information, written to ASIC by Morgans director of legal and compliance Jennet Butler, was headlined “options business” and highlighted problems with a former operation at the Gold Coast’s Burleigh Heads. Ms Butler is not accused of wrongdoing.

She wrote ASIC had acknowledged Morgans' “pro-active response in relation to the ex-Burleigh Heads operation but is mindful, given the serious and likely extended level of Corporations Act contraventions identified, that a more extensive, group-wide [Morgans] response may be required”.

ASIC has not publicly linked any problems to that Morgans office.

It has banned trader Rodney Peters, who had worked there, from providing financial services for six years, ruling he had wrongly “represented to clients that he had authority to engage in discretionary trading”. But ASIC said he was punished for actions that occurred between 2015 and 2016, three years after he left Morgans.

The freedom of information emails also list 2015 problems with derivatives trading with Michael Taylor from Morgans' Caloundra branch. Mr Taylor, who has previously maintained he tried to do the right thing by clients, was last year permanently banned by ASIC from providing financial services for problems occurring during his Morgans stint.

Legal actions

Morgans has been sued in dozens of former client actions in Queensland courts since 2013 for alleged problems in at least four branches. It has defended some matters but one lawsuit this year revealed it had also settled claims from more than 60 clients.

Advertisement

Following a series of problems across the organisation, ASIC and Morgans brokered an agreement in 2015 that resulted in the stockbroking outfit accepting restrictive licence conditions.

Restrictions were lifted this year with praise about Morgans' reforms from a compliance consultant.

ASIC told the Financial Review when the licence conditions were imposed in 2015 that the breaches identified under the Corporations Act did not contain any “offence or civil penalty provisions”.

Given the options available in 2015, ASIC said it was satisfied that “licence conditions were a strong regulatory outcome”.

Civil penalty proceedings would be an option under changes introduced in March this year, ASIC said.

Morgans declined to answer questions but said it was “committed to ensuring all clients receive an exceptional professional service”.
description: Even as the stockbroker knew of breakdowns at a branch, an ASIC memo shows it was disputing client compensation claims.
